thread.title: What's new at Fall for Greenville
thread.title_full: What's new at Fall for Greenville

title: What's new at Fall for Greenville
text:
What's new at Fall for Greenville Donna Isbell Walker , diwalker@greenvillenews.com 2:33 p.m. EDT October 8, 2015 Fall for Greenville brings out large crowds to enjoy the good weather, good food and music with plenty of activities for the kids. (Photo: KEN OSBURN) CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
This year's Fall for Greenville, which opens at 5 p.m. Friday in downtown Greenville, won't be all food, fun and frivolity. 
Festival organizers are collecting donations for flood victims in South Carolina's Midlands and Lowcountry areas. Those attending can donate cash or Fall for Greenville Taste Tickets, which will be collected at beverage vendors around the festival site. The money will go to disaster relief organizations.working in the Columbia and Charleston areas. 
In addition, the festival will pay tribute to law enforcement officers, firefighters and EMS personnel, with a special hospitality tent offering free meals and refreshments throughout the three days of the event. The tent, sponsored by Bravo1 Protection, will be located on Broad Street and is limited to first responders. 
Fall for Greenville will feature 38 restaurants and 60 musical acts, as well as culinary demos, restaurant competitions and a children's area. 
Here are a few things you need to know if you go: 
•The festival runs along Main Street, from North Street to Augusta. Road closures, in addition to Main Street, include East Washington, from Main to Spring; Falls Park Drive, from Rhett to Main; Broad Street, from Laurens Street to Falls; McBee Avenue, from Laurens Street to Spring; Brown Street, from Coffee to McBee; and Court Street, from Laurens Street to Spring. 
•Free shuttle service, provided by Greenlink, will be available throughout the weekend. Park-and-ride locations will be at the Kroc Center, University Center and Greenville County Square. Buses begin running an hour before the start of the festival and continue until an hour after the festival closes. 
•Bike valet service, sponsored by Bikeville, will be provided Saturday and Sunday between noon and 6 p.m. near the Carolina Ale House Stage on East McBee Avenue. 
•Parking in city-owned garages is a flat $6 rate for the day. 
•New to this year's festival is the Aloft Social Media Lounge, located at ONE City Plaza. People can check out festival highlights and social media updates, and take photos at the "selfie wall." There will be prize giveaways as well. 
•Taste Tickets are required to purchase food, beverages and amusement rides in the children's area. Tickets are $5 for a sheet of eight, and are sold at ticket booths throughout the site. A $1 city of Greenville wristband, also sold at ticket booths, is required in order to purchase or consume alcohol, and a valid ID is required. 
•Organizers are still looking for volunteers to work the festival, and walk-ups will be accepted at Volunteer Headquarters, located on The Greenville News Plaza at South Main and Broad streets. 
•Pets, lawn chairs, blankets and coolers are not allowed on the festival site, and smoking is not permitted. 
•Festival hours are 5 to 11 p.m. Friday, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m. Saturday, and noon to 7 p.m. Sunday. 
Fall for Greenville By the Numbers: 
150,000: Expected attendance 
2,000: Number of volunteers it takes to put on the festival 
1.4 million: Taste Tickets sold last year 
11: Number of states festival-goers came from in 2014 
98: Percentage of downtown Greenville hotel occupancy for last year’s festival 
38: Participating restaurants 
250: Number of menu items for sale 
36: Craft beers available in the Beer Garden 
60: Musical acts 
1: Musical act performing with kazoos 
3: Locations offering park-and-ride shuttle service to the festival 
6: Entertainment stages
